research_focus: Active Spectroscopy Framework for Stratospheric Aerosol Injection
core_hypothesis: Small-amplitude, information-optimized pulsed SAI (multi-sine/PRBS/chirp) can be used as active probes in Earth system models to identify frequency-dependent gains, lags, and nonlinear distortions in the climate response. This yields compact, generalizable surrogate models for control design and provides early-warning indicators (phase drift, harmonic growth) of instability that outperform passive, continuous-injection baselines. Frequency-domain system identification under designed perturbations is the most direct and data-efficient way to answer how temporal modulation changes outcomes; simpler passive observation or one-off impulses cannot recover the same spectral and nonlinear structure.
experimental_protocols: E1. Active probing design and identifiability
E2. Frequency response and nonlinear distortion
E4. Early-warning via phase drift and harmonic growth
technical_methods: Information-optimal probe signal design (multi-sine, PRBS, chirp)
Frequency-domain system identification using spectral regression
Second-order Volterra kernel estimation for nonlinear characterization
Fisher information maximization under environmental constraints
Early-warning indicator development via phase drift analysis
